thread.title: Wildcats rally in second half to nip Northeast
thread.title_full: Wildcats rally in second half to nip Northeast

title: Wildcats rally in second half to nip Northeast
text:
Wildcats rally in second half to nip Northeast Tony Centonze, For The Leaf-Chronicle 11:14 p.m. CDT October 8, 2015 Buy Photo Northeast's Quinton Cross fumbles the ball as he crosses the goal line, but the Eagles recovered in the end zone to take a 14-0 lead on Clarksville High in the 2nd quarter Thursday at Northeast High School. CHS won the game 17-14 (Photo: Tony Centonze/For The Leaf-Chronicle) Buy Photo CONNECT 2 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
CLARKSVILLE, Tenn. â€” Northeast High started strong against rival Clarksville High Thursday night, jumping out to an early 14-point lead. 
But the Wildcats launched a comeback that started with about 5:30 left in the second quarter, and the Cardiac Cats, as they are sometimes called, managed to score 17 unanswered points to rally to a 17-14 victory in a Region 7-5A game at the Eagles Nest. 
It was the first game back for Clarksville coach Isaac Shelby, who spent five years at the helm at Northeast High, guiding the Eagles to a pair of state quarterfinals and one state semifinal before taking the CHS coaching job two years ago. Buy Photo 
Clarksville High's J.J.Jones stretches to try to catch a pass but came up just short in the end zone Thursday against Northeast. The Wildcats won, however, 17-14. (Photo: Tony Centonze/For The Leaf-Chronicle) 
Trying to avoid a third straight loss, Clarksville looked sluggish to start with three fumbles as Northeast jumped out on the Wildcats. 
The Eagles' Quinton Cross scored early on a 2-yard touchdown run at the 11:40 mark in the first quarter. Cross also carried in the Eagles' second score of the night, an 11-yard run, with 5:33 left in the opening quarter. 
But from that point on, it was all CHS. Despite the fumbles the Wildcats were able to hold Northeast scoreless for the remainder of the game. Brevon Johnson cut the lead to 14-7 after a 1-yard run with 10:21 left in the fourth quarter. Quarterback J.J. Jones took in a touchdown run that tied the game at 14 midway through the final period. 
But the biggest moment of the night came from Clarksville kicker Caden Patterson, who executed two onside kicks that the Cats were able to recover. The first came at the start of the second half to surprise the Eagles (3-5, 1-4), and the other would result in a fourth-quarter field goal to give them their first lead of the night, 17-14. 
Clarksville improved to 6-2 on the season and more importantly 3-2 in region play. That keeps the Wildcats in the fourth, and final, playoff spot with two more games remaining. The Wildcats will face Dickson County in two weeks and wrap up the regular season at Brentwood. Read or Share this story: http://leafne.ws/1Rx3OSI TOP VIDEOS
